resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
Il bodin (Pudding)
The classic recipe speaks of chocolate pudding, and in fact this dessert was all the rage in Goldoni's time. There were then several ways to prepare it, and one of the most popular involved the use of egg yolks, sugar, flower, milk and grated chocolate. A very homogeneous and fluid mixture was prepared, which was placed on the fire, always stirring, allowed to thicken, then poured into a mold, enriched with a little rosolio (rose liqueur) and placed in a cold place until it was time to send it to the table. Then one would turn the mold upside down on a serving plate and the pudding was ready.
resource.chars:
Il bodin (Pudding)

The classic recipe speaks of chocolate pudding, and in fact this dessert was all the rage in Goldoni's time. There were then several ways to prepare it, and one of the most popular involved the use of egg yolks, sugar, flower, milk and grated chocolate. A very homogeneous and fluid mixture was prepared, which was placed on the fire, always stirring, allowed to thicken, then poured into a mold, enriched with a little rosolio (rose liqueur) and placed in a cold place until it was time to send it to the table. Then one would turn the mold upside down on a serving plate and the pudding was ready.

item.value: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><path xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" d="M287.01559,1044.19777h52.69096v0h52.69096v22.76461v22.76461h-52.69096h-52.69096v-22.76461z" data-paper-data="{"strokeWidth":1,"rotation":0,"annotation":null,"nonHoverStrokeColor":["Color",0,0.74902,1],"editable":true}" id="rectangle_75c9475b-6f78-4592-adc8-b90fb51104ae" fill-opacity="0.00001" fill="#00bfff" fill-rule="nonzero" stroke="#00bfff" stroke-width="5.45455" stroke-linecap="butt" stroke-linejoin="miter" stroke-miterlimit="10" stroke-dasharray="" stroke-dashoffset="0" font-family="none" font-weight="none" font-size="none" text-anchor="none" style="mix-blend-mode: normal"/></svg>

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
Il fricandò (Stew)

This is a stew and is more specifically a very thick cut of veal, larded with bacon. A chopped garlic and onion is prepared and stir-fried in oil and butter then the meat is placed to brown and bathed in white wine. Chunks of celery and carrot, stalks of parsley, a few bay leaves and a sprinkling of cinnamon, clove powder and nutmeg are added. Ladles of hot water are poured over it, salt is added, and it is slowly cooked with the pot closed and over low heat. When the meat is cooked, it is cut into slices and sent to the table, hot or even warm, with its own sifted cooking juices and accompanied by spinach or peas or mixed vegetables.
resource.chars:
Il fricandò (Stew)

This is a stew and is more specifically a very thick cut of veal, larded with bacon. A chopped garlic and onion is prepared and stir-fried in oil and butter then the meat is placed to brown and bathed in white wine. Chunks of celery and carrot, stalks of parsley, a few bay leaves and a sprinkling of cinnamon, clove powder and nutmeg are added. Ladles of hot water are poured over it, salt is added, and it is slowly cooked with the pot closed and over low heat. When the meat is cooked, it is cut into slices and sent to the table, hot or even warm, with its own sifted cooking juices and accompanied by spinach or peas or mixed vegetables.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
La Frittura (Fried Food)

Many dishes were prepared with this technique in Venice: first of all, fish, which could be of a single quality, such as sardines, sardoni, sfogi, passarini, little mullets, cuttlefish, squid, etc., or of more than one species, resulting in the famous mixed fried foods still popular in Venetian cuisine today. Then there were fried giblets, such as brains, livers, etc.; but also vegetables, such as castraure (artichokes of first flower), zucchini slices, squash blossoms, mushrooms, etc. However, the cooking technique was almost always the same: you would pass the piece to be fried to white flour, then to egg and breadcrumbs and dip it in a very hot fat, which was oil, butter or lard. It was immediately sent to the table, with a sprinkle of salt and, if you liked it, a few drops of lemon.
resource.chars:
La Frittura (Fried Food)

Many dishes were prepared with this technique in Venice: first of all, fish, which could be of a single quality, such as sardines, sardoni, sfogi, passarini, little mullets, cuttlefish, squid, etc., or of more than one species, resulting in the famous mixed fried foods still popular in Venetian cuisine today. Then there were fried giblets, such as brains, livers, etc.; but also vegetables, such as castraure (artichokes of first flower), zucchini slices, squash blossoms, mushrooms, etc. However, the cooking technique was almost always the same: you would pass the piece to be fried to white flour, then to egg and breadcrumbs and dip it in a very hot fat, which was oil, butter or lard. It was immediately sent to the table, with a sprinkle of salt and, if you liked it, a few drops of lemon.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
L'Arrosto (roast)
Another important dish of eighteenth-century Venetian cuisine, prepared on the spit with very slow cooking. The meats used were numerous: duck, capon, guinea fowl, pork, chicken, turkey, all game and also veal and beef. Garlic, rosemary, and sage were used to flavor the meat, and the leaner animals were wrapped with slices of bacon.
resource.chars:
L'Arrosto (roast)

Another important dish of eighteenth-century Venetian cuisine, prepared on the spit with very slow cooking. The meats used were numerous: duck, capon, guinea fowl, pork, chicken, turkey, all game and also veal and beef. Garlic, rosemary, and sage were used to flavor the meat, and the leaner animals were wrapped with slices of bacon.

item.value: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><path xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" d="M755.14598,974.02257h66.88152v0h66.88152v24.18054v24.18054h-66.88152h-66.88152v-24.18054z" data-paper-data="{"strokeWidth":1,"rotation":0,"deleteIcon":null,"rotationIcon":null,"group":null,"editable":true,"annotation":null}" id="rectangle_f3ea15d2-82a0-4d6c-b54c-41d600dc6f9c" fill-opacity="0" fill="#00bfff" fill-rule="nonzero" stroke="#00bfff" stroke-width="1" stroke-linecap="butt" stroke-linejoin="miter" stroke-miterlimit="10" stroke-dasharray="" stroke-dashoffset="0" font-family="none" font-weight="none" font-size="none" text-anchor="none" style="mix-blend-mode: normal"/></svg>

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
Il Lesso (Boiled Meat) 

This is the most popular dish in the bourgeois kitchens of the 18th-century Venice and was prepared with different kinds of meat, especially capon, chicken, turkey, breast and head of veal, mutton and sheep. Meats with a few pieces of bone were placed in a pot with cold water, flavored with a clove-studded onion, one or more stalks of celery, a few carrots, parsley stalks, and one or more cloves of garlic. Once cooked, the meats were kept warm in a nice copper pot, immersed in their broth. When it was time to serve them, they were sent to the table accompanied by special sauces.
resource.chars:

This is the most popular dish in the bourgeois kitchens of the 18th-century Venice and was prepared with different kinds of meat, especially capon, chicken, turkey, breast and head of veal, mutton and sheep. Once cooked, the meats were kept warm in a nice copper pot, immersed in their broth. When it was time to serve them, they were sent to the table accompanied by special sauces.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
The carne pastizzada (Stew)
A piece of red meat was taken, marinated in wine flavored with garlic, onion, carrot, celery, rosemary, sage, thyme, bay leaf, marjoram and with cinnamon, cloves and nutmeg, brown it in a stir-fry of oil and beaten lard, cover it with the marinade, bring it to a boil and then lower the heat and cook it slowly with the pot covered for several hours. When the meat was cooked, it was cut into slices that were sent to the table with some of the cooking sauce. The meat could be in one piece or in fairly large pieces, and in this case a large stew was obtained that was very tasty.
resource.chars:

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
La zuppa (Soup)

When people in Venice speak of soup, in a generic way, they mean either fish soup or clams soup or oxtail soup or even herb soup, tripe soup, or, the simplest of all, broth and bread soup. Soup by its nature is very liquid, brothy and wants bread to soak in, but today's soups are very little reminiscent of those in vogue in the eighteenth century. Let us mention here a few of the soups recalled by saying at once that, contrary to what one might believe, sopa de pesse (fish soup) was not very common in Venice, while it was more present in the small towns on the edges of the lagoon, Chioggia and Caorle above all. Sopa de cape (clams soup) was more readily available and was made with one or more of the many varieties of shellfish found daily on the market. To prepare it, one would start with a stir-fry of oil, garlic, and parsley, remove the garlic as it browned, and add the desired amount of cape to the stir-fry. When these opened, they were poured with their cooking tocio (broth) into a bowl, in the bottom of which a layer of bread slices had been laid. A little hot beef broth was added, a grating of piasentin cheese and the dish was ready. Sopa de coa, i.e. beef tail soup, was prepared by boiling a skinned and chopped beef tail with celery, carrot and onion in a pot of salted water. When the broth was ready it was strained and poured into a tureen over slices of bread, with the usual grated cheese added.

Ladles of hot water are poured over it, salt is added, and it is slowly cooked with the pot closed and over low heat. When the meat is cooked, it is cut into slices and sent to the table, hot or even warm, with its own sifted cooking juices and accompanied by spinach or peas or mixed vegetables.
